title: At home  hv123
description:
Welcome back! You are about to start the theme 'At home'.
 It is about homes and housing.
How are you going to practise?
 You are going to practise your writing, reading, listening and speaking skills. You will visit websites, play games, do exercises and listen to stories.

items.content:
Dear pupil,

Welcome back! You are about to start the theme 'At home'.
It is about homes and housing.

How are you going to practise?
You are going to practise your writing, reading, listening and speaking skills.
You will visit websites, play games, do exercises and listen to stories.

What are you going to do?
You are going to read, listen, speak and write about homes and housing.
By practising a lot your English will improve!

Need help?
Use the toolbox if you need help. Here you will find (new) words and expressions. You will also find help for grammar and pronunciation.

Have fun!

Before starting to work in this theme, check with a classmate how much you know about homes and housing in English already.

House and home
To start with, it is important to know the difference between 'house' and 'home'.
Read the following website and discuss with a classmate what the difference between the two words is.

  • How can you relate the following expressions to this explanation?
    Home sweet home
    Home is where the heart is
    It takes a heap of living to make a house a home

  • Do you know other words or expressions related to 'house' or 'home' that show the difference between the two?
Listen to the song by Antebellum, called 'Home is where the heart is'.

At the end of this theme you:

  • will have listened to people talking about (their) homes and houses;
  • will have read descriptions of people's houses and their rooms;
  • will have practised vocabulary about homes and housing and prepositions of place;
  • will have learned and practised the present continuous, the past continuous and relative pronouns (betrekkelijke voornaamwoorden);
  • will have written descriptions of various houses (rooms, furniture, location);
  • will have spoken about your house in English;
  • will have learned more about houses in England and houses of indigenous people from America, Australia and New Zealand;
  • will have designed your own future (futuristic) dream house.

But you don't have to be able to do this right away!
If you take the following steps you'll find out what you need to know!

Work plan
There are many exercises in each theme.
It is important to know which exercises you have done and which exercises you haven't done. To help you, there is a work plan.
On this work plan you can tick the exercises you've done.

Click here to download the Workplan At home

Ieder thema bestaat uit een groot aantal opdrachten/oefeningen.
Het is belangrijk dat je goed bijhoudt welke opdrachten je gedaan hebt. Om je te helpen hebben we een werkplan gemaakt.
Op dat werkplan kun je bijhouden welke onderdelen je al gedaan hebt.

Download hier het Werk plan At home

In this part you will practise your listening skills.
There are different listenings, but they are all about houses, housing or homes in some way or another.

There are listenings on:

  • Clare's house
  • Mark's ideal home
  • Buying a house
  • World's greenest homes
  • Home swap

By listening to English (and doing many exercises) frequently you will improve your listening skills and your English!

Good luck!

Before you begin, read these tips:

Before you start listening:

  • Read the introduction carefully.
    This will help you understand what the listening exercise is about.
  • Read the questions.
    This will help you find the information you are listening for.

While you are listening:

  • Focus. If you miss the first part of the listening exercise, it is very difficult to understand the second part of the listening exercise.
  • If you have heard the answer, fill it in and move on to the next question.
    Don't wait too long!
  • If you are not sure about the answer, just pick the answer you think is best.
    If you doubt you risk missing the answer on the next question.

Have fun!

Clare speaks about her house in England.
Listen to the audio and answer the questions.

You have listened to the audio once. Now, read the questions and discuss them with a classmate. Do you know the answers yet?

  1. Does she live in a big house or a small house?
  2. How many rooms does it have?
  3. Is it a new house or an old house?
  4. What is in her kitchen?
  5. What does she watch on TV?

Answer the questions you did not answer yet and check the answers you have.
You have listened to the description of Clare's house twice.
If necessary, you listen to the audio again, while reading the text.
Look words you do not know up in a dictionary.

Todd: OK, Clare we're going to talk about your house.
Clare: OK.
OK, do you live in a big house or a small house?
Clare: I live in quite a big house.
Todd: A big house. Really!
Clare: Mm!
Todd: OK, how many rooms does it have?
Clare: About 12.
Todd: Jeez! 12 rooms.
Clare: Yeah.
Todd: Wow. Is it a new house or old house?
Clare: It's about 80 years old.
Todd: Wow. OK. I guess. well that's old for America, but that's probably not very old.
Clare: That's not very old for England.
Todd: Wow. OK. What is in your kitchen?
Clare: A big round table and a cooker.
Todd: OK. And what is in the living room?
Clare: A TV and a video.
Todd: OK. Do you watch TV a lot?
Clare: Yes.
Todd: OK. Uh, what do you watch on TV?
Clare: Anything. I don't really like watching sport.
Todd: Oh.
Clare: I like watching TV series.
Todd: Oh, wow, that's the only thing I like is sports
Clare: Some sports are OK. I don't like watching golf, snooker, and sports like that.
Todd: Yeah. OK. Great. Thanks.

prompt.body: Listen to the audio and tick the topics you hear in the boxes below:
Listen to the audio and tick the topics you hear in the boxes below:
Listen to the audio and tick the topics you hear in the boxes below:

items.content:
You are going to listen to Mark speaking about his ideal home.
Before you listen, do the following exercise.
Write difficult words or words you do not know down in your notebook.

You should now be prepared for the listening.
Listen to the audio and answer the four questions.
Listen two times if necessary.

prompt.body: Very large and expensive house
A garden (AmE)
The person living next to you
What a piece of land looks like
The room where wash yourself
The room where you cook.
A space in a house
Wat vindt Mark belangrijker dan wonen in een enorm groot huis?

content.body: Dat zijn familie in de buurt woont.
Dat hij dicht bij zijn buren woont.
Dat hij wat ruimte om zijn huis heeft.

prompt.body: In wat voor omgeving staat Mark's ideale huis?

content.body: In de buurt van een grote stad.
In een omgeving met heuvels, bomen en meren.

prompt.body: Hoe ziet de ideale tuin van Mark eruit?

content.body: Wel een beetje bijgehouden, maar niet perfect.

prompt.body:
Wil Mark een grote of kleine badkamer?<br xmlns="" />
En wat zegt hij over de keuken?

content.body: Hij wil een kleine badkamer en een grote keuken.
Hij wil een grote badkamer en een kleine keuken.
Hij wil een grote badkamer en een grote keuken.

items.content:
Do you have your own house or do you rent one?
Together with a classmate think of the advantages and disadvantages of owning and renting a house.
When people buy a house, there are many things to consider!
In this section, you are going to listen to someone who speaks about the process of buying a house. Before you listen, make sure you know what the following words mean.
They will all be in the listening!

college to move
convenient inconvenient
realtor bedrooms
buyer seller
to afford offer sheet
to bid tough

Now you're going to listen to Mike and Todd.
Mike is looking for a new house and speaks about the process of buying a house.

Answer the questions. Listen two times to the audio, if necessary.

After answerring the questions, read the text.
Look words you do not know up in a dictionary.

Todd: Michael, this is a beautiful home.
Mike: Yeah, we've lived here for about twelve years and it's too big for us now.
Todd: Really. It's pretty big.
Mike: Well, yeah, I mean, it's got four bedrooms and it's got this big living room area and dining room area, and I've got two kids and both of them are in college now, so they don't live here anymore. (Oh) So my wife and I are thinking about, you know, moving to a smaller house.
Todd: Oh, that makes sense. Well, so where are you going to move?
Mike: Well, this area is called Walnut Creek, it's in the East Bay of San Francisco, and we want to move into an area that's in the Berkeley Hills. It's called Orinda.
Todd: Oh, yeah. That's nice.
Mike: Oh, it's very nice. I mean it's a little more inconvenient, and it's not as convenient as here (Yeah) but it's a little more, there's more privacy, and there's more nature, you know more like old established trees and hills, and a little quieter, and so all those things appeal to us, so we're looking. It's not easy to find a right place but we're, actually today we're gonna meet a realtor, and we're going to be looking at some houses that are available and see if you like any of them.
Todd: You know, actually, I've been thinking about getting a house. I'm kind of getting up there in age. What is the process of buying a house? Like how do you go about it?
Mike: Well the first step to find a place is you, generally you have to work with a realtor, somebody who has access to homes that are for sale, and then you sort of look through the listings and you find ones that you like, that you can afford, and then you visit with the realtor, and say you find a house that you like, like there is one that we're going to visit today that we think we like and we're going to check it out again. After we visit we make an offer sheet, we draw an offer sheet, that says how much we're willing to pay for the house, and the owner looks over the offer sheet. They never meet us directly, they meet only through their (the realtor) the realtors talk to each other. The buyer and the seller never actually talk to each other directly, and in this case, the house is going to have multiple offers. Many people will want this house.
Todd: OK
Mike: So they're not going to look at the offers until next week, and say five or ten people bid on it, they're probably going to take the one, the person who offers the most money for it, so it's competitive.
Todd: That is a tough situation.
Mike: Yeah, so sometimes you'll find a house that you love, and you can afford, but somebody outbids you. Somebody bids more for the house than you do and you lose it, and you have to keep looking so it can take weeks of months.
Todd: Wow, well
Mike: To find the house you want.
Todd: Sounds tough. Good luck.
Mike: Thanks a lot

prompt.body: Why do Mike and his wife want to move to a smaller house?

content.body: Because their current house is too expensive.
Because their current house is too big.
Because their current house is too old.

prompt.body: The place they want to move to is:

content.body: Quieter than the place they live now.
Cheaper than the place they live now.

prompt.body: What is true about the house Mike and his wife are going to visit that afternoon?

content.body: Mike and his wife do not like it very much.
More people want to buy it.
Mike and his wife have made a bid.

prompt.body: What is true about the house Mike and his wife are going to visit that afternoon?

content.body: Someone places a lower bid than you.
Someone places a higher bid than you.

items.content:
You are going to watch 'world's greenest homes', a programme in which people's green homes are shown. The episode you're going to watch is called 'Casa Neverlandia'.

Discuss with a classmate:
Looking at the name 'Casa Neverlandia', what do you think the house
will look like? Move on to the next stage to find out what the house looks like.

You are now going to watch the video (until 1:17).
In this part, the house, its background and its owners are introduced.
Read the questions before watching the video and answer them while watching the video.

  1. Where is the house?
  2. What rooms are mentioned?
  3. Where does the name of the house come from?
  4. What is the background of the owner of the house (James)?
  5. What do they say about the material the house is built with?

World's greenest homes - Casa Neverlandia

You are now going to watch the whole video. Do so in three steps:

  1. You repeat the piece of video you have already seen to answer the questions on page 1 (until 1:17). At 1:17, stop the video and check your answers.
    Discuss them if necessary.
  2. You start the video from 1:17 onwards. Answer the following two questions.
    Watch this piece of the video two times if necessary.
    1. What objects are mentioned? (Write down everything you hear).
    2. How is the house energy sufficient?
  3. Discuss your answers to questions 2a and 2b with a classmate.
    Watch the video (1:17 - end) again to check your answers. Of course you can also add information to your answers if they were not complete yet.

World's greenest homes - Casa Neverlandia

Discuss:

  • In what way(s) are you energy efficient or eco friendly in your house?
  • Brainstorm ways to save energy with a classmate.
  • How important do you think it is to live an eco friendly life?

Home swapping
You're going to listen to a six minute conversation about 'home swapping'.
Any idea what 'home swapping' is?
Look the word 'to swap' up in a dictionary and discuss with a partner what you think home swapping is.

Before you listen to the conversation, take two minutes to make a list of topics that are related to home swapping. Write down anything you can think of.

Now listen to the audio. Which of the topics from your list* were mentioned?

To add a bit of competitiveness to this task, get pairs to check each other's lists.

You have now listened to the audio once. On this page you can also read the text.
Look words you do not know up in a dictionary.
Download: Text Home swap

Question: Do you think you would ever try 'home swapping'? Why (not)?

In this part you will practise your reading skills.
You are going to read texts on:

  • Rooms in a house
  • Home swapping
  • Rooms to rent
  • Being home alone

By reading a lot in English (and doing many exercises) you will improve your reading skills and your English!

We wish you pleasant reading!

Before you start reading:
Don't start reading straight away (= meteen).
First look at the title, the image and highlighted words.
These can help you understand what the text is about.
Read the introduction and the questions first.
They will give you a better idea of the text.
With multiple-choice questions, look at the options and try to see what the differences are.

While reading:
It will be very difficult to understand everything you read.
If you see a word you do not know, it is very important to ask yourself if this word is important to understand the text.
If you understand the text without knowing the word, there is no need to use
a dictionary. If the word is important to understand the text (and/or to answer questions) go ahead and use your dictionary! Just make sure you don't use the dictionary all the time because it costs too much time.

In this reading, you are going to read about the various rooms in a house and what is normally in these rooms.
In this text Erik writes about houses in England.

Procedure:

  • Take two sheets of paper (one for every floor).
  • Read the text on Woodlands.
    Do not forget to click on the arrow below the text to move to the next page!
    You do not have to read the 'Houses in England' part.
  • Draw the rooms that are typical of the ground floor on one of the two sheets of paper.
  • Draw the rooms that are typical of the first floor on the other sheet of paper.
  • Compare your drawing to that of a classmate to see if you have the same rooms (on the same floor).
  • Read the text again. This time, write the names of typical objects (as mentioned by Erik) in each room.
  • Compare the objects you wrote down for each room with a partner again.
    • Do you have the same objects for the same room?
    • Are there any objects that could go in another room too?

Extra challenge!
The text you have watched is very rich in material!
That is why there is a extra task for those who want...

  • Work together with a partner.
  • Take an object (from the reading text) in mind.
  • Your partner asks yes/no questions to find out what object have in mind.
    For example: Is the object in the kitchen? Yes/No

Home Exchange Vacation
Have you ever exchanged homes with anyone?
Do you know anyone who has?

In this section, you're going to have a look at a home exchange vacation website.

  • Click on the link www.homeexchange.com to go the the website.
    • Kijk maar eens of je een leuk huis kunt vinden waarmee jullie wel mee zouden willen ruilen. Dat kan zonder in te loggen.

    Selecteer op de kaart een land/gebied waar je naartoe zou willen.
    Klik door tot je bij de beschrijving van het huis bent.
    Lees de beschrijving van het huis.
    Vertaal de beschrijving van het huis.
    Vertel een klasgenoot waarom je voor dat huis hebt gekozen.

You are going to stay in Cambridge for a while!
That is why in this section you are going to look for a room/flat/house to rent.
The website www.zoopla.co.uk is going to help you.

Before you go to the website, answer the following questions.
Write down difficult words that you want to remember in your notebook.

You are now ready to start looking for a room, flat or house.
Go to www.zoopla.co.uk .

Look for a place to stay paying attention to the following:

  • Your parents do not want to pay more than €500 per calendar month
    (use a currency converter if necessary!).
  • You do not want to share the house with more than two other people.
  • You want the best value for money.

prompt.body: The house is for sale.
She has a room to let / rent in her house.
The value of their house has doubled.
He owns several properties in the centre of London.
Estate agents sell properties.

items.content:
You can search for anything that meets these criteria.
Consider possibilities as for example renting a two bedroom apartment (and get a tenant for the other room).

Show what you've found to a classmate. Do you have similar properties?
Explain each other why you have chosen the property.

Possible extension: Vote for the best value for money option in class!

Have you ever seen any of the 'Home Alone'-films? How did you like them?
Do you think the boy can take good care of himself?
Do you think this is a normal situation?

In this section, you are going to read a text about being home alone. Many children in the US are home alone for part of the day.

  • Are you home alone?
  • From what age onwards?
  • Did you speak about it with your parents?
  • What did you speak about?
Together with a partner, make a list of topics that parents should consider (= overwegen) before leaving their children home alone.

Now read the text. Do not worry about words you do not understand.
You are going to look at them on page 2.
Home Alone: Are you ready?
Did you know that in the U.S., almost half of all kids aged 6 to 13 are home alone for part of the day? The boy in the Home Alone movies certainly had fun, but the whole experience can be freaky sometimes. These days, even a lot of adults are scared to be alone in the house! It's TOTALLY understandable if you, or someone you know, are nervous about being home alone.

Your parents think you're ready, but do YOU?
At first it sounds cool to be home alone, right? Think of the freedom you'd have around the house! There's nobody to stop you from playing video games or watching your favorite TV show!
So there you are, listening to that CD your parents hate. Then: what's THAT? You hear a noise outside. It sounds like it could be a person on the front doorstep, and there's been a string of robberies in the area lately. Suddenly, your unsupervised freedom doesn't feel so safe any more.
It's a normal feeling and it doesn't mean you're a "baby." There's always stuff going on in the world to shake our feelings of security. You might feel totally fine about being alone when you're 10. Then, two years later, something happens that makes you feel different about it. Every person and every home environment is unique.
If you have worries about being home alone, it's really important to speak up about them, even though it may cost money to get a sitter or your parent has to rearrange his or her schedule.

How do you know if you're ready? Ask yourself these questions.
If you answer "no" to any of these, talk to a parent about some solutions that will help you get prepared.
  • Do you know what to do if there's an Emergency Situation like: a fire, a bee sting, a sister who's choking, a knock at the door, an allergic reaction, a natural disaster (earthquake, tornado, flash flood)?
  • Can you respect the house rules set by your parent/guardian?
  • Can you take care of your basic needs, such as snacks, drinks, homework, etc. while still following the house rules?
  • Are you able to entertain yourself if you don't have homework?
Maybe you're a home-alone pro and answered "yes" to all the questions. Good going! Now you can take it even farther and make sure you know how to be safe during your time alone.

Bron: pbskids.org

Answer the following questions.

  • Which items of your list were mentioned?
  • Which items were in the text and not in your list?
  • Which items were on your list and not in the text?
  • What is the target group of the text? What does the writer try to make clear?

You have a general idea about the text 'Home Alone' now.
You're now going to look at the text in more detail.
To start with, you are going to focus on reading strategies.
The bold parts in the following sentences (from the text) can be difficult to understand at first sight.
However, when you read the words in context, you do not need a dictionary to understand what they more or less mean.
With a partner, try to guess what kind of meaning the bold words/expressions have.
Then check your ideas in a dictionary.

  1. The boy in the Home Alone movies certainly had fun, but the whole experience can be freaky sometimes.
  2. So there you are, listening to that CD your parents hate. Then: what's THAT? You hear a noise outside. It sounds like it could be a person on the front doorstep, and there's been a string of robberies in the area lately.
  3. Suddenly, your unsupervised freedom doesn't feel so safe anymore. It's a normal feeling and it doesn't mean you're a "baby." There's always stuff going on in the world to shake our feelings of security.
  4. There's always stuff going on in the world to shake our feelings of security.
  5. Do you know what to do if there's an Emergency Situation like: a fire, a bee sting, a sister who's choking, a knock at the door, an allergic reaction, a natural disaster (earthquake, tornado, flash flood)?
  6. Maybe you're a home-alone pro and answered "yes" to all the questions.

You should now be ready to answer some questions about the text!
You can read the text again to answer them.

Possible extension: adjectives to describe feelings
If you have time left, or simply if you feel like, have a look at the adjectives to describe feelings in these sentences.

  1. These days, even a lot of adults are scared to be alone in the house!
  2. It's TOTALLY understandable if you, or someone you know, are nervous about being home alone.
  3. You might feel (totally) fine about being alone when you're 10.
  4. If you have worries about being home alone, it's really important to speak up about them [...]

Answer the following questions.

  1. Are they positive or negative?
  2. How are the adjectives used?
    For example: a lot of adults are scared to be alone (to be scared + to infinitive).
  3. Have a look in a dictionary.
    Are there other uses of form (question 2) possible?

prompt.body: What proportion of US children aged 6 to 13 are home alone for part of the day?
Adults are never scared to be alone in the house.
In the second and third paragraph of the text [At first … not so safe any more], the writer:

content.body: Shows examples of advantages and disadvantages of being home alone.
Shows examples of the advantages of being home alone.

prompt.body: In the second and third paragraph of the text [At first … not so safe any more], the writer:

content.body: Shows examples of advantages and disadvantages of being home alone.
Shows examples of the advantages of being home alone.

prompt.body: In the fourth paragraph [It's a normal feeling … is unique], the writer:

content.body: Explains why he/she thinks being home alone is a unique experience every time.
Explains why it is not a problem to be scared of being home alone.

prompt.body: The writer thinks:

content.body: It is important to think about your parents' schedule when you speak about being home alone.
It is important to talk to your parents if you do not like being home alone.

prompt.body: If "no" is your answer to any of the four questions under 'How do you know if you're ready?':

content.body: You should speak to a parent about how you can make this answer a "yes".
You should prepare your parents to find a solution.

items.content:
The toolbox is a kind of treasure chest!
In the toolbox you will find:

  • Grammar
  • Words
  • Pronunciation
  • Typing game
  • Taaldorp
  • Fun
  • Reference

You are going to study some grammar items, (new) vocabulary and
pronunciation. All of them are important parts of a language and will help you to improve your reading, listening, speaking and writing skills.
There are games to play as well (in 'fun') and there is a reference entry in which you will find useful websites to help you while you are working your way through the theme.

Good luck!

Grammar
To be able to read, listen, speak and write better, you will need to know your grammar!
In this theme you are going to repeat or learn more about:

  • Present continuous
  • Past continuous
  • Relative pronouns (betrekkelijke voornaamwoorden)

For each grammar item, there is an explanation and there are exercises.
Try to do as many exercises as possible!

Good luck!

Have a look at Kennisbank Present continuous.

Grammar: Present continuous


Now you are ready to do the following exercises.

If you like to practice extra:

  • Present continuous

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?
In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: He likes standing on his head.
He is standing on his head.

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: The weather has been getting better.

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: What are you doing this evening?
What will you be doing this evening?

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: The number of accidents is falling rapidly.
The number of accidents falls every year.

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?
In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: Is he watching an interesting movie?
Has he been watching an interesting movie?

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: I have been repairing my bike.

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: Come on, we're waiting for you.
Come on, we have been waiting for you.

prompt.body: In welke zin is de present continuous gebruikt?

content.body: We're going to my sister's tomorrow.
We go to my sister's tomorrow.

Deze oefening gaat over de present continuous.
Je krijgt een aantal zinnen met gaten te zien.
Welke woorden moeten ingevuld worden?
Vul steeds de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in.

  • I (watch) an interesting movie.
  • Sue (read) a book.
  • We (play) football.
  • They (work) at the moment.

Deze oefening gaat over de present continuous.
Je krijgt een aantal zinnen met gaten te zien.
Welke woorden moeten ingevuld worden?
Vul steeds de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in.

  • He (stand) on his head.
  • I (cycling) to school.
  • The weather (get) better.
  • Look! Sam and Tom (play) football.

Deze oefening gaat over de present continuous.
Je krijgt een aantal zinnen met gaten te zien.
Welke woorden moeten ingevuld worden?
Vul steeds de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in

  • The teacher (explain) the lesson.
  • Listen! Susan (play) the guitar.
  • We (go) to my sister's tomorrow.
  • You (swim) with our clothes on.

prompt.body:
Zet de werkwoorden tussen haakjes in de juiste tijd.

I ... (work) in an office from 9 to 5, but at the moment I ... (work not).

Zet de werkwoorden tussen haakjes in de juiste tijd.

Every day Sarah ... (go) to school by bus but now she ... (cycle) to school.

Zet de werkwoorden tussen haakjes in de juiste tijd.

Sam, what ... you ... (do)? I ... (swim) with my clothes on.

Zet de werkwoorden tussen haakjes in de juiste tijd.

James normally ... (work) as a butler but now he ... (play) football.

items.content:
Have a look at kennisbank Past continuous.

Grammar: Past continuous


Now you are ready to do the following exercises.

If you like to practice extra:

  • Past continuous

content.body:
Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de past continuous.

  • I (watch) a film.
  • We (enjoy) the countryside when we spotted something was wrong.
  • John (work) for this firm in the 1970s.
  • Jack (do) his homework when Susie rang and asked him out.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de past continuous.

  • She (have) a bath when the telephone rang.
  • We saw a lot of rubbish when we (walk) through the park.
  • My friend (paint) the door when someone came in.
  • He (play) tennis from 3 till 4 yesterday afternoon.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de past continuous.

  • What you (do) last night at seven?
  • They (do) exercises all morning.
  • Pamela (read) a book when her mother arrived.
  • Jack (smoke) a cigarette when the headmaster saw him.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de past continuous.

  • Brendon (repair) his motorbike when his mother called for dinner.
  • When my mother opened the door, my friend and I (kiss) in the hall.
  • When her dad came in, Jaimy (eat) crisps.
  • I (have) a shower when the telephone rang.

Now you are ready to do the following exercises.

items.content:
You finish the grammar section with a grammar test.
If you pass the test you are ready for the next step!


Good luck!

prompt.body:
Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik de present continuous.

I I ..... (watch) an interesting movie.

II He ...... (stand) on his head.

content.body: I = am watching II = is standing

prompt.body:
Maak de zin af. Gebruik de present of present continuous.

James normally …I… (work) as a butler, but now he …II… (play) football.

&amp;amp;#160;

content.body: I = is working II = is playing

prompt.body:
Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik de past continuous.

I I ..... (watch) an interesting movie.

II We ...... (enjoy) the contryside.

content.body: I = was watching II = do enjoying
I = was watching II = were enjoying

prompt.body:
Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik de past continuous.

I John ..... (work) for this firm in the 1970s.

II Jack ...... (do) his homework when Susie rang and asked him out.

content.body: I = was working II = was doing
I = did working II = was doing

prompt.body:
Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik de past continuous.

I What ..... you ..... (do) last night at seven?

II Tom and Eve ..... (play) tennis from 3 till 4 yesterday afternoon.

content.body: I = was doing II = are playing
I = was doing II = were playing
I = were doing II = are playing
I = were doing II = were playing

prompt.body:
Maak de zin af. Gebruik de past of past continuous.

When my mother …I… (open) the door, my friend and I …II… (kiss) in the hall.

&amp;amp;#160;

content.body: I = was opening II = were kissing

prompt.body:
Maak de zin af. Gebruik de past of past continuous.

We …I… (drive) to Glasgow, when we …II… (run) out of petrol.

content.body: I = were driving II = were running

Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik het juiste betrekkelijk voornaamwoord.

I The man ..... spoke is my father.

II The car ...... he bought was very cheap.

Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik het juiste betrekkelijk voornaamwoord.

I Do you know the boys ..... are throwing stones at us?

II I didn't like the girl ...... was swearing at me.

Maak de twee zinnen af. Gebruik het juiste betrekkelijk voornaamwoord.

I The chair on ...... I was sitting broke down.

II The crowd, ...... was very angry, began to shout.

items.content:
To do all the exercises in the theme 'At home', it is useful you know words and sentences to speak or write about homes and housing.
For every theme you can find words and sentences on www.wrts.nl . You need to be registered to enter the word lists. If you are not registered, register on this page . If you're already registered at wrts.nl, sign in and start learning words and sentences with WRTS.

Go to http://wrts.nl/studiovoengels and log in.
Look at the lists and pick one. For this theme there are five lists:

  • At home A
  • At home B
  • At home C
  • At home chunks A
  • At home chunks B

Click on the word: 'Overnemen' behind the list you want to learn.
You now see the list, scroll down and click on 'Opslaan'.
Click on 'Overhoren'. Choose a way in which you'd like to practise.
Then click 'Begin overhoring'. Practise in different ways.
Good luck!

On this page you will find some links to useful other vocabulary exercises about homes and housing.

  • Internetpolyglot (extra word lists on house, furniture and household objects). Practise the vocabulary with different types of exercises (tuturial slideshow, guessing game, typing game, matching game, mix game)!
  • Explanation of the difference between 'house' and 'home'
  • Interactive guide: inside the British home.
    See how domestic spaces evolve from Saxon times to the post-modern era
  • Different rooms in a house and their furniture
  • Prepositions of place (in, at, on)

There is a lot of "house-vocabulary" to be found on www.languageguide.org/english too.
Have a look at the pronunciation section in the toolbox for the links to various sections.

At languageguide.org you can practise the pronunciation of some important words in this theme!

  1. Place the cursor over the images.
  2. Listen to and practise the words by saying the words out loud.
  3. Choose the 10 most difficult words from each exercise.
  4. Write them down in your exercise book or in a Word file.
  5. Read them aloud to another pupil.
  6. Show your teacher what you have learned!

In this theme you are going to practise the following topics:
> The house > The garden / the yard > Indoors
> The den / living room > The dining room > The bedroom
> The utility room > The kitchen 1 and The kitchen 2
> The bathroom 1 and the bathroom 2

Remember: This is American English.
The British English pronunciation is sometimes different!
Sometimes they even have different words for the same thing!

Typing game

Je gaat een typwedstrijdje spelen.
Je krijgt een aantal woorden/woordcombinaties te zien.
Kijk steeds goed naar de spelling van het woord/de woordcombinatie.
Typ het woord of de woordcombinatie daarna zo snel mogelijk na.
Als je in het totaal 100 letters of meer hebt getypt, stopt het spel.
Hoe hoog is je score?

Klik op de link om het spel te starten:
> Typwedstrijd At home - Flash

Don't forget to pay a visit to the virtual village!
You will be visiting a house with many exercises inside.
They will help you repeat important words in a fun way.
Try to do as many exercises as possible!

Please write down the exercises you've done on your work plan.

  • Taaldorp: Home - Flash

Have fun.

Leerlingen voor leerlingen
Op de website www.lvoorl.nl vind je verschillende video's die door leerlingen voor leerlingen zijn gemaakt.

Hieronder een video die goed past bij het thema 'At home'.
Bekijk de video en bespreek de inhoud van de video met een klasgenoot.

House furniture

Here some fun websites that have to do with homes and housing:

  • You're in charge
  • Prepositions of place
  • Furniture memory
  • Bathroom Rally
  • Pirate Waters bathroom game
  • Bathroom vocabulary memory game
  • Pirate waters bedroom vocabulary
  • Bedroom moonshot game
  • Bedroom vocabulary memory game
  • Kitchen vocabulary memory game

Have Fun!

If you need more help with grammar or vocabulary while you are studying,
have a look at the following websites:

  • www.macmillandictionary.com
  • learnenglish.britishcouncil.org
  • www.vertalen.nu
  • simple.wikipedia.org
  • www2.research.att.com
  • www.google.com

In 'speaking' you will be working on your speaking skills.

First you are going to have a look at some useful expressions (warming up).
Then you're going to practise a conversation with the help of speech cards and evaluate a conversation of classmates (speech card).
Finally, you are going to practise your speaking in some real-life situations (speak up). On the final page of speak up, there are some conversation questions about houses and homes.

In these exercises you're going to speak about homes, houses and housing.

With every exercise you do, your speaking skills will improve!

Speak up!

Before you start speaking:

  • First look at the instructions.
  • Try to think of words and expressions you might need.
  • Use as many expressions as possible; you can use them if you're lost for words.
  • DON'T write out your conversation or talk completely!
    If you do that, it will just be a writing and reading exercise!

While speaking:

  • Make sure you start a conversation by greeting the other person in a polite way.
  • Look at your partner or at your audience.
  • Speak calmly and not too quietly.
  • You can use a note, but make sure there are only a few words on it!
  • If you don't know a word, you can always explain what you can use it for, or what it looks like.
  • Try to keep on talking, even if you don't really know how you should say something.
  • If you don't understand your partner, you can ask for an explanation,
    or ask your partner to repeat the question.
  • End a conversation by saying goodbye.

Clue: if you practise a conversation a second time, it will be much easier!

In this section, you are going to practise some sentences and expressions that you will need for the speaking exercises.
Of course, the words and grammar sections are very important too (and have more exercises) so go back to them for repetition if necessary.
You start with an exercise on the rooms in a house.


Furniture
Most houses have a living room, a kitchen, a (or more) bedroom(s) and
a bathroom. Do you know which piece of furniture is where?


Conversation
Complete the conversation.

prompt.body:

keuken

slaapkamer

zolder

badkamer

badkamer

studeerkamer

Choose the correct translation.

kelder

Choose the correct translation.

woonkamer

Choose the correct translation.

serre

Choose the correct translation.

eetkamer

Choose the correct translation.

gang
What sort of house have you got?

content.body: Wat voor een auto heb je?
Wat voor een huis heb je?
Wat voor een kamer heb je?

prompt.body: What's your address?
I live in a terraced house.

content.body: Ik woon in een vrijstaand huis.

prompt.body: We live in a nice neighbourhood.

content.body: Wij wonen in een leuke wijk.

prompt.body: We have a house of our own.

content.body: We hebben allemaal een eigen kamer.

prompt.body: We rent a house.
We are renovating our house.
The toilet is in the hall.

content.body: De toilet is in de badkamer.
De toilet is in de gang.

prompt.body: How many rooms have you got?
Have you got a bath or a shower?

content.body: Hebben jullie een bad of douche?

Fill in the right words to the right sentences.
first floor - garden - semi-datached - bedrooms - dining-room - swimming pool - ground floor

  • Inge: I live in a house in the suburbs of Paris.
  • Ann: What is it composed of? Inge: On the , you can find the kitchen, the and the lounge and also the bathroom.

Fill in the right words to the right sentences.
first floor - garden - semi-datached - bedrooms - dining-room - swimming pool - ground floor

  • Ann: Where are the ?
  • Inge: My parents' bedroom is on the on the front of the house. My bedroom is at the back of the house. Ann: Do you have an attic?

Fill in the right words to the right sentences.
first floor - garden - semi-datached - bedrooms - dining-room - swimming pool - ground floor

  • Inge: Yes we do, one part of it is used as a lumber room, and the other part is where we can play billiards. Ann: What about the ?
  • Inge: The garden is at the back of the house, it is quite large. There is a terrace where we have barbecues and a at the back.

items.content:
Speech card
Here are some sentences that can be useful to prepare the speech card.

How do you:

prompt.body: introduce yourself on the telephone?
say you like the fact you speak to the other person?
thank someone for his/her reaction on your ad(vertisement)?

content.body: Thank you for your reply on my ad(vertisement).

prompt.body: ask someone to describe their house to you?

content.body: What about your house? What is it like?
Could you (please) describe your house to me?

prompt.body: ask someone to say something about local attractions near his/her house?

content.body: Do locals pay for attractions near their houses?
Could you tell me something about local attractions nearby?

prompt.body: say you think you have found what you were searching.

content.body: I think this is exactly what I'm looking for!
Well, this is not exactly what I was searching.
I think I'm searching for a bigger house.

items.content:
Speech card
Now you are going to have a conversation about your house with a classmate.
Imagine you and your classmate have met on a home exchange website.
You and your families want to exchange homes and have arranged to meet on skype because you both think it is more personal than emailing.

Procedure

  • Find someone to work with and decide who is person A and
    who is person B
  • Download your speechcard. Take some time to (look up and) write down
    a couple of words to help you during the conversation. If you need help, use a dictionary, go to the 'Words' section in the toolbox, or have a look at the warming up section.
  • You and your classmate put your chairs back to back.
    Practise your conversation at least twice.
  • Go to page 2.

Speech card - beoordeling
After practising twice, do the following things:

  • Find another pair to work with. Act out your conversations.
  • Give feedback to each other. Use the Speech card - beoordeling to do so.
  • Discuss what things were good and what you can do better next time.

Have fun!

You now get a chance to practise your speaking in various different situations that are all related to the theme. Try to practise as many as you can!

If you have enough time, use the peer-feedback form: Feedback sheet

Hi neighbour!
You and your family are in an exchange home in England.
You meet your neighbour. Think of some questions (and responses) to ask to you neighbour.
Practise your conversation with a classmate.
Make sure both of you act out both roles.

Evaluation
Jullie hebben het goed gedaan als:

  • jullie eraan gedacht hebben elkaar te groeten;
  • jullie elkaar een aantal goede vragen konden stellen;
  • julie antwoord konden geven op de gestelde vragen;
  • jullie het gesprek netjes afgerond hebben.

Floor plans
You are going to work together with a classmate.
One of you downloads floor plan A and one of you downloads floor plan B .
Have a look at your floorplan and take some time to prepare describing it to your classmate.

Task:
Each of you takes a blank sheet of paper (A4). Decide who starts first.
Describe your floor plan to your classmate. Your classmate needs to draw what he/she hears. When the description has finished, compare the drawing to the floor plan. It is important that the floor plans are not shown to each other during the description!

Tip:
It may be interesting to record the floor plan descriptions (with a mobile phone for example).
You would then:

  1. listen to the description and draw according to what you hear
  2. compare your drawing to the floor plan and
  3. listen to a recording of the description to correct your drawing (without looking at the floor plan obviously).

Home swap
You and your family are on holiday in an exchange home in Scotland.
Your exchange home is a big, detached house. One day, you meet the neighbour in the garden, he asks you what your house in the Netherlands looks like.
Tell him what kind of house it is, how many rooms it has and something special about your house. Practise the conversation with a classmate. Make sure both of you act out both roles.

Here some conversation questions on houses and homes:

  • What do you like about your home? What don't you like?
  • How many different homes have you lived in?
  • What changes would you like to make to your present home?
  • What are the things in your home you couldn't live without?
  • Who are your neighbours? Do you get along well with your neighbours?
  • Imagine you have arrived in a country where they don't speak your language. You have no money or friends there. What would you do for accommodation?
  • Make a list of the ten most important things you would look for when choosing a house to live in.
  • What do you think houses will be like in the future? Draw your future house.
  • Which are the advantages and disadvantages of living in a small house/flat/apartment? And living in a big one?

Introduction
In this part you are going to improve your writing skills.
You are going to practise writing about houses and homes in English.

If you keep practising, writing will become much easier!

Have a look at the toolbox (reference) if you need help.

Good luck!

Tips for writing
Read these tips for writing and keep them in mind while doing the exercises.

  • Try to make a planning of your writing (what do you want to say?
    In what order (= volgorde)?
  • Try to use words and sentences you already know (see toolbox, words).
  • If you need to find the correct English word, or if you are unsure about the spelling of a word, use a dictionary (see the 'reference' section in the toolbox).
  • If you write your letter on the computer make sure that the spelling checker is on English.

It would be very strange to start your email by 'Hi there!' when you write to someone you do not know yet. This person may actually think you are a bit crazy!

In email writing, it is very important that you know the right expressions for formal and informal email. Formal emails are emails written to people you do not know. They are normally very correct. Informal emails are emails you write to friends or other people you know. They can be a bit more playful. There are also emails we would call 'neutral', they are in between formal and informal emails.

In the next exercise, indicate which of the two expressions is more formal.
That does not mean it is necessary a (very) formal expression; it simply means it is more formal than the other expression. Do not forget to write interesting lines down in your notebook!

What general differences do you see between formal and informal language for writing? What happens to contractions (e.g. I'm) in formal language?

prompt.body: Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:
Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:
Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:

content.body: I am writing with regard to …

prompt.body: Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:
Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:

content.body: Could you give me some information about …
Can you tell me something more about …

prompt.body: Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:

content.body: Do not hesitate to contact me if you need further information.
Let me know if you need anything else.

prompt.body: Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:

content.body: I am looking forward to … (+ ing form).

prompt.body: Indicate which of the two expressions is more formal:

items.content:
You have found a wonderful house you'd like to swap with during the summer.
Send an email to the owner of the house (John Whitton) and his family.

Write:

  • who you are;
  • that you read his advertisement on homexchange.com;
  • who you will be travelling with;
  • what you like about his / her house;
  • what kind of house you have (location, attractions near your house, number of rooms, names of rooms).
    Look at the descriptions on wwww.homeexchange.com if you need inspiration;
  • when you want to swap homes;
  • that you look forward to hearing from him / her soon.

Tips:

  • Do you think this email should be formal, neutral or informal?
    Be consistent with formal, informal or neutral language in your email!
  • Have a look at the toolbox (reference, words) or the warming up section for help.

Leaving a comment
You and your family have swapped homes with the Whitton family (see 'Email for homeswap'). You have had a great experience and want to leave a positive comment/review on the homeexchangeplace.com website for the Whittons.

Have a look at the house of the Whittons first on the website www.homeexchangeplace.com .

Write about:

  • the good contact you had with the Whittons (nice and informal, quick responses to your emails);
  • what you liked about the house (clean and think of two other things yourself);
  • what you liked about the environment.

This is the real stuff! Here are some real-life situations to practise your writing skills. Practise as many situations as you can!
If you need help, have another look at the toolbox or the 'tips' section!

Fill out a form
Your family has decided to join the homexchange homeswapping network.
To do so, the following form needs to be filled out. Download the form and fill it out for your family. Ask your teacher how to hand it in.

Describe your home
After registering at www.homexchangevacation.com , you need to add
a description of your house to your profile. People who want to exchange homes with you should see what your home is like.
Describe:

  • how many rooms there are in your house (and what kind of rooms they are);
  • the space outside the house (garage? garden?);
  • the environment.

Make sure your description stands out from the crowd!
If you need an example, go to homexchange.
Ask your teacher how to hand the description in.

House rules
Your parents work a lot!
They want to start to leave you and your little brother and sister home alone for two days a week. As you're the oldest child, you get quite a lot of responsibility!
That is why your parents want to speak about house rules for when they're not there with you.
Think of ten important house rules for you and your siblings when your parents are not at home and write them down.

Ask your teacher how to hand your house rules in.

What do you know about Great Britain, British culture and other English speaking countries?

You are going to learn more about them in 'Life and culture'!

In this theme you will look at housing of the English and of indigenous people from North America, Australia and New Zealand.

Get started!

You are going to read about English houses on the woodlands website .
Read the information and answer the following questions.

Do you think housing in the Netherlands is similar?
Have a look if you can find similar information for the Netherlands on the Internet!

prompt.body: Where do most English people live?
Which of these sentences about people in Great Britain is true?

content.body: There are more people who own a house than people who rent a house.
There are more people who rent a house than people who own a house.

prompt.body: A mortgage is ...

content.body: money you pay to the bank to pay for your house (the house is yours).
rent you pay to a landlord or landlady to pay for your housing (the house is not yours, you rent it).

prompt.body: A semi-detached house is a combination of ...
A terraced house is a combination of ...
What is the comparison between 2003 and 2007 (under cost of houses) meant to show?

content.body: That house prices grow faster than people's wages.
That people's wages grow faster than house prices.

items.content:
Indigenous people
Any idea what 'indigenous people' are? Have a look on the internet to find out. What are the indigenous people of North America, Australia and New Zealand?

In this section, you are going to prepare a collage about houses of the indigenous people of North America, Australia or New Zealand.

Procedure:

  1. Your teacher will divide your class into three main groups. Group 1 makes a collage about the houses of indigenous people from North America; group 2 about the houses of indigenous people from Australia; group 3 about the houses of the indigenous people from New Zealand.
  2. Work in groups of three to four pupils. Search for information on the Internet. Make a collage about the houses of your indigenous group of people. Try to find some remarkable information about the houses!
  3. Exchange information with people from two other groups so that you get information on all three groups of indigenous people.
  4. Write about 250 lines about the different types of houses of the three groups of indigenous peoples. Write about for example what materials they used for their houses, whether they had rooms in their houses or not, how they stayed warm, where they cooked, where they slept, etc.

In this part you will find a language task that combines various language skills.

The task in this theme allows you to finally design your futuristic dream house! No worries about money, just let your dreams come true!

Get your fantasy to work and move on to the task!

My future (futuristic) dream house
Make a poster with a design of your future (futuristic) dream house. You are free to design your house the way you like it, but it must be "green". Sources that may be of use when designing your future (futuristic) dream house are
'Grand designs' and 'World's greenest homes' (both to be found on Youtube).

The poster should include / point out:

  • A floor plan of your future (futuristic) dream house: ground floor, first floor (second floor) and garden. Names of the rooms should be written in them. You can use floorplanner.com to help you planning your space if you like.
  • Images of what the various rooms will look like (3 pieces of furniture for each room included).
    You can use www.italiadesigns.co.uk or www.designfurniture.com.au to look for pieces of furniture to 'glue' into your rooms.
  • The eco friendly devices / installations in your house.
  • The location of your future (futuristic) dream house.
  • Three main rules to be followed in your future (futuristic) dream house.

Who do you think designed the best house in your class?
Who designed the most eccentric house?
Who designed the most eco-friendly house?
